name: Blood Bowl - Legendary Edition
description: Inspired by the Warhammer Fantasy world, Blood Bowl is an ultra-violent combination of strategy and sports games. The Legendary Edition features 20 playable races, including 11 that are totally new, each offering its own game style! Make a competitive team, train it and buy the best equipment.

Intel, SIS and Via/S3G graphics controllers non-supported DirectX®: 9.0 Hard Drive: 5 GB Sound: DirectX® 9 compatible Multiplayer Requirements: Internet connection required for online gameplay.

reviews.review_text: Its a faithful board game conversion that I am certain (despite rampant criticism) does not cheat. Unfortunately, the AI is so bad I sometimes wish it did. Even so, the game is fun in single player and more fun in multiplayer. As for the board game itself, it is strategic and occaisionally random enough to make it interesting. Game balance is kind of wacky (in the board game as well, some teams are difficult to play on purpose) but this only adds to the charm in my opinion. The bragging rights one wins when scoring a touchdown as the Halflings counts as a buff in my book.

I loved this game, Khemris are so fun to play, crushing other players is SO fun! If you liked the boardgame then you must want to get it already, but for the newbies i'll try to describe why this game is so good. The number of teams is really nice because each team represents different playstyle : the humans are pretty much balanced and you'll be able to throw passes or run through the opponent's line whereas elves' playstyle is based mainly on passes and dodging tackles due to their agility, Khemris will try to litteraly crush the opponent's line to get their holder of the ball to the touchdown because they can't do a single pass while gobelins will play dirty by using unconventionnal weapons during the match such as chainsaws, pogo sticks etc... At the beginning you'll be a little lost if you didn't play the board game because nearly nothing is explained, you'll have to read the rules book and that will take you about 1h to get through this but when you master the rules it gets really fun. You should start by playing the campaign mode because that's how you'll learn most easily.

Blood Bowl is an awesome game, full of trolls and orks and violence and football. Or rugby. Kind of a rugbyfootball. I had never played the miniature game, but having grown up in comic and game shops, was exposed to it and always loved the concept. As far as I can tell and from what my buddies tell me, this is very faithful to the core mechanics of the miniature game, as well as the teams available and rules for how to make up your teams.  Don't be fooled by the single player feature, this is a multiplayer game. Unlike most games however, this isn't not a pick up and play game. Don't get me wrong, you can, but this is a game designed around leagues and competition.  There are thousands of laughs to be had and I reccomend this game to anyone who loves tactical strategy titles. When your star player reaches level 5 when most other players in the league are 2 at most, you'll really learn what Blood Bowl is when you watch him die as the medics fail to revive him because an angry fan threw a rock at him.
Love me some Blood Bowl, it really takes me back. I don't quite remember rolling double/triple skulls so often on the board game, though.
I like this game a lot and I even found cake.

I have been a fan of the game since its original version of the mid 80's (which was cardboard cut-outs) and every version since. BB is one of the most well designed games ever produced by Games Workshop, and the classic timed *turn-based* computer version is a faithful emulation of the boardgame. The game has three formats--the classic version of the game, the classic version with some additional rule variants and customization options (which can be fun), and the 'real-time' Blitz version. Of the three versions, the most fun for me is the classic version with or without the variants. I do not enjoy the Blitz version of the game at all. Regardless, the title is worth owning. For me, the replay value is very high and I especially enjoy playing against my son in multiplayer mode.
This game is fun but unforgiving at times. Praying to the Blood Bowl God's may increase your favour and your luck!

I have over 500 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.   One Hour Reviews #26 - Blood Bowl: Legendary Edition  I had heard of Blood Bowl, and knew it was based on a tabletop game, but otherwise I did not know anything about it. So going in, I had no idea what to expect.  Since I hadn't played before, I started with the tutorial, hoping it would help me understand how to play the game. After waiting awhile for it to load (longer than I would have expected), it opens with a pair of commentators to explain the rules of the game, with some groan-worthy humor thrown in.  The tutorial starts out simple enough by explaining the basic camera controls, and how to change cameras. Then it covers 'tackle zones' and placing your teams starting positions for the kick off. It also explains the concept of re-rolls, which allow you to re-roll a die result, with each team only getting a limited number of these.  But things quickly get complicated once the actual gameplay starts. The game is filled with all of these different skills that players can have. Each skill acts as a conditional modifier, depending on the situation. For example, when picking up the ball, the game will 'roll a die' and if the roll is too low, then you'll fail to pick up the ball. But, if your player has the 'Sure Hands' skill, then the player gets a second roll when the first one fails.  It seems that pretty much every action in the game has one of these skills associated with it. If I try to pass the ball, there's a 'Pass' skill that lets you re-roll a failed roll. The game also starts talking about stats like Agility, and some kind of 'Agility Table' that is used for skill checks, but apparently you have to read the rules to see that.  Next the tutorial moves onto blocking and pushing past defenders. Now even more skill checks are coming into play. Here the roll is based on the Strength stat, and not only are there skills for influencing the block result, but also whether or not players get injured or not.  As the tutorial continues into movement, dodging and blitzing, and even more die rolls and skills, I can feel my eyes starting to glaze over. By the time the tutorial gets to the first turnover, I am pretty much lost. I'm just kind of reading and nodding along at this point.   Just to give an idea of how quickly the tutorial starts piling on skills, here's one of the things it tries to explain to me: 'Since Krug Painspear has the tackle skill, Jean-Paul mussen is knocked down with a 'Defender Stumbles', even though he has the Dodge skill, which would normally allow him to regard that as a simple push-back.'  The commentators swear that although it sounds complicated, it's all really easy after a few games. I'm not so sure. I'm reminded of this episode of Star Trek where Kirk has been captured by these gangsters, and he introduces them to a card game called Fizzbin. Only the game doesn't exist, and Kirk is making up the rules as he goes, and the gangsters are completely confused as Kirk tries to explain the game. That's exactly how I felt after finishing the tutorial.  So clearly there is a learning curve here. So it comes down to whether or not it's worth spending the time to learn the game. If you are a fan of the board game, then it seems pretty obvious you'll enjoy this as well. If you like tabletop war games in general, and aren't intimidated by rules, then it's also likely you'll enjoy this. But if you are more of a casual player, then this game will likely go right over your head as it did mine.

Others would say this game is a good one, but I say, nope.  Here's why: RNG is not random at all. There's no random anything, because I've seen dice rolls before, for this game on table top, and they aren't nearly this one sided even in the worst of cases (mini wargaming has videos with them playing this table top version, and even then they aren't nearly this bad). Difficulty setting? No reason to lie, its hard, extra hard, might as well not play. Actually, I'm wrong, it goes: don't bother, don't bother, don't bother. No change to difficulty changes any part of the game. Meaning that you put it on easy? It's still going to bend you over, put it on hard, it still, guess what, bends you over. They make dodge after dodge, gfi after gfi, single dice blocks and double against and nothing happens. The player? First dodge fails, or second dodge fails (I haven't done double dodge moves because of this), single dice blocks are attacker down 90% of the time, rerolled into attacker down or both down, and double against? Might as well buy another player at that point.  This is the worst case of RNG I have seen in a game, in forever. There's no reason the dice couldn't be actually ballanced or the rolls be actually random.  I wouldn't buy anything from this dev, so long as it's a game that's supposedly an adaption of a table top game. Since they have BB2, and the reviews are down right ugly for that game, I will not be purchasing or playing this game again.  And if you've gotten this far, and wonder how someone could say such things about this game without playing it for a while? Look at how many hours I've logged, and you can see I have given this game way more time than it actually deserves.  1/10. The one is for graphics, since these, although clunky and weird at times, do make the game look semi nice.  I urge you, as a final note, not to get this game if you haven't already, and if you have, don't get BB2, you can read their reviews and see the issues, but lets face it, they took a turd, polished it, and handed it back to you... What's that saying? Polish a turd, its still a turd?

An amazing yet infuriating game set in the Warhammer universe. Blood Bowl takes a turn based approach to American Football and with the help of a unique roster of 20+ races and factions, turns it into a violent and chance based struggle to the endzone. The less patient or and those easier to become enraged at RNG may not like it as you live and die by the dice and a single bad role can turn something as innocent to trying to pick up the ball into a bloodbath with multiple players dead and the enemy right at your endzone for the next turn. However, those that play and enjoy the game will learn and be able to do amazing things like kill the ball carrier, then retrieve the ball with another player, pass it to the team's star gutter runner (if you built a skaven team) and have him run all the way down the field dodging numerous defenders... only to break his neck when he trips in front of the endzone since once again, you live and die by the dice.

Blood Bowl: Legendary Edition is a fantasy football video game with the option for turn based or real time game play. This game is an expansion to Blood Bowl that was developed in 2009 by Cyanide and published Focus Home Interactive and is based on the board game 'Blood Bowl' that is produced by Games Workshop.  Blood Bowl: Legendary Edition has a great variety of game modes available for both single player and multiplayer that will keep you entertained for days providing the dice gods don't come down on you too harshly. It is however recommended that you play using Classic mode and playing using turn based due to the fact that blitz mode is an awful edition to the game since it does not fit in well and functions clumsily.   There are a 20 races to choose from in Blood Bowl chaos edition and helps to add a nice variety to the teams for come up against, some races share similar players but overall there is a lot to choose from and picking what team you want to play as can take quite some time.  It is recommended that you purchase Blood Bowl: Chaos Edition due to it having a similar price depending where you purchase it from and adding an extra 3 races for you to play.  Blood Bowl: Legendary Edition graphics are perfectly suitable for what it is trying to achieve and generally looks visually pleasing and adds a fair amount of detail into the surroundings and units, for a game made in 2009 you defiantly can't complain about the graphics.  On lower difficulty settings the AI make irrational moves that tend to lead to costly mistakes, while the higher levels of AI provide some challenge but you most likely will want to look for opposition using multiplayer.  If you want a faithful recreation of the board game Blood Bowl this is the only video game you should currently choose to try out due to the fact that it is quite high quality and is a quite compelling experience overall. I highly recommend that you give this game a try if you like a challenging board game-esque strategy game.  Rating - 8 - A must buy!   Advantages  - Compelling Game play  - Lots of variety - The best of its kind on the market   Disadvantages - Irrational AI at lower difficulties

Blood Bowl is an interesting concept and has huge potential, but the single player campaign is punishingly difficult thanks to slavishly following the rules of the board game. Let alone which, the difficulty selection is bass-ackwards; if you set the difficulty to Easy, the opposition will take more chances, and as the game relies on the luck of the dice-roll, this means they'll do better. However, while the randomness of dice-rolling is a weakness in single player, I could see it being a massive benefit in multiplayer. It's just a shame that I have no desire to play this game competetively whatsoever.
If you like football/rugby, turn-based strategy games, and Warhammer or at least two out of the three. Then you should get this or Chaos Edition.

Blood Bowl is one of those games that is hard to determine if you should recommend it or not. Humour is good, gameplay isn't bad either, yet sometimes the game gets just too infuriating for some reason. So I'm going to list the pros and cons of this game, and you can make your mind yourself.  Pros: Good dose of dark humour from the two commentators. Great variety of teams/races to play with. Different play modes, and you can even edit the rules. Blood, violence, and random, untinkable, kills (an elf single-handedly killing a minotaur? Who knew?) Lots of skills, equipment, etc.  Cons: Steep learning curve. Curve is so steep, it could be called a wall. Yes, the tutorial explains most of the gameplay, but there is too much 'For this, reffer to the manual'. Said manual is about 80 pages... Evasion system is maybe too easy. With 4 Agility (base Agi for Agi-based players), there is just about nothing that can stop you Battle system can also be somewhat flawed, as if you are against a strenght-based team, they will only put all their players around the one carying the ball, and due to the odds, you are very unlikely to stop even one of them.  Long story short, if you play this game, expect to lose, expect to get frustrated, expect that what you though to be a good strategy was a bad one. If you are unsure, buy this game while on sale, as it often seems to be.
